qas.question: What kind of cables does the fully featured USB Type-C contain?
Electronically marked cables have a chip that contains what?

answers.text: an ID function based on the configuration data channel and vendor-defined messages

qas.question: What is the shortened version of vendor-defined messages?

context: Full-featured USB Type-C cables are <a0_0>active, electronically marked cables<a0_0/> that contain a chip with <a1_0>an ID function based on the configuration data channel and vendor-defined messages<a1_0/> <a2_0>(VDMs)<a2_0/> from the USB Power Delivery 2.0 specification. USB Type-C devices also support power currents of 1.5 A and 3.0 A over the 5 V power bus in addition to baseline 900 mA; devices can either negotiate increased USB current through the configuration line, or they can support the full Power Delivery specification using both BMC-coded configuration line and legacy BFSK-coded VBUS line.
